key_points: Hurricane Larry is expected to grow into a Category 4 hurricane by early Sunday with sustained winds of 140 mph.
Currently, Larry is moving west with 85 mph winds, located 875 miles west of the Cabo Verde Islands.
Larry's forecasted path keeps it well east of Puerto Rico as a Category 3 hurricane by early Tuesday.
Computer models predict Larry may track near Bermuda, but its exact path remains uncertain.
Another area of low pressure has a 20% chance of tropical development as it moves toward the Yucatán Peninsula and the far western Gulf of Mexico.
A second low pressure area shows signs of organization and has a 30% chance of development within the next two days.
Remnants of Hurricane Ida caused multiple fatalities in Montgomery County, Pennsylvania, and at least nine deaths in New York and New Jersey.
Major flooding from Ida impacted highways, commuter services, and caused historic flooding predictions in the Philadelphia area.
New York City's subway system faced severe disruptions due to flooding, with videos showing cars filled with water.
The next named storms will be Mindy and Nicholas, with Sept. 10 marking the peak of the hurricane season.
